author: masteredbyjack
content:
Okay here we go…

@ALXCPH found a couple on my camera roll. Excuse quality, one is when I showed my parents the studio for first time. Couple (long) notes…I’m sure @Nomograph Mastering can expand if he chooses:

Unf*ck designed the room. Ruairi you are incredible at this and I’m very grateful. The subtleties in the trade offs when designing a room are something I urge everyone to consider deeply as I learned when working with them!

1. Studio is built in my basement…13 feet long x 30 wide x 8 tall (including treatment). Back wall divides it length wise and makes the studio part 12x15 approx.

2. All treatment is built in…entire ceiling is stuffed with 9 inch pink fluffy, couple inch rockwool in the walls, tuned mass loaded vinyl behind the “housings” to L and R of listening position. Back wall is 6 inches of safe n sound in a frame built of 2x8s (by contractor) with a 24” door. It’s standing by friction just slid tight to ceiling. Quite precise measuring required to do that and make it sturdy so a door can open well

3. Since I get asked a lot…the wall finishes are acoustic felt board. Went that direction because install was way better than a fabric wall (they are firm and can be cut with an exacto knife). Also they are absorptive with no reflections…caveats apply if that’s good for a given space though (rather than the acoustically transparent fabric).

5. @BatMeckley can confirm hard front wall was farrrr superior for me. I had a soft one (felt) against Ruairi advice since I preferred the aesthetic lol, but room was too dead. Uncomfortable. When I switched I could hear much more depth and energy but everything still as crisp and clear. Highly recommend! 

Hope this helps some people on here. FYI we started my room from concrete block, bare bones so could frame things to hold treatment needed.

Will circle back with some better pics when I’m home. This community has helped me greatly.

Cheers friends!

author: cian riordan
content: If you're doing vocals on hardwood or tile floor, rugs are great for nabbing first reflections off the floor. Most of what is bouncing back into the microphone is in that slappy high end area and will likely sound bad. With a guitar cab, the microphone will sit quite a bit lower to the ground -- so in theory this idea is even more useful. However, program-material depending, its likely whatever is coming out of the speaker is going to drastically overpower what gets slapped up from the floor. If there's a rug around I'll typically use it for these situations.

author: cian riordan
content: I think the attack wall solves the problem for people that can't build their room from scratch. As someone that just built a studio, building fake walls with insulation & membranes tucked behind aint cheap. And it's permanent. Having tube traps (or the ASC pressure traps, or whatever they are) are not a panacea -- but rather a scalable, portable method of getting an untreated room in the ballpark. I've found with tube traps that more is not necessarily better and you just don't know till you get in there and shoot it. My friend Andrew Maury raves about his. He's gets amazing results and he loves moving around his setup every few months just because he likes tweaking... and the attack wall allows him to do this. So -- if you're building a studio from the ground up, there are absolutely better options. But if you're hopping around from space to space and don't feel like spending $10-15k on framing, fabric, rockwool, & building limp mass membranes... these are a terrific option.

author: EliHeathMusic
content:
I’m attaching pictures to show how they are constructed. Basically you make a box with rough plywood, brace it, add rockwool, stretch fabric over it, add trim pieces and then attach the 2 by 4s with wheels. 

Some tips:
-The finish pieces should be a little over an inch longer than the internal frame pieces: 1 inch to account for the added length of 2 sheets of 1/2 inch plywood and a little extra to get over the fabric. This time I cut them 1.25 inches longer and had to sand down the top and bottom trim pieces a little.
-Predrilll pilot holes as much as possible to avoid splittling the thin plywood. For the finish pieces I also did “diy countersinks” using a larger drill bit in order to have the screws be flush with the wood. 
-Stretch the fabric tight but not so tight that it warps the frame in the middle. Start by stapling on the long sides at each end of the middle brace, then work out from the center stopping a foot or two away from the corners. Then staple the centers of the short ends and finish with the corners. I staple every 6 inches or so and each time I add a staple I try to pull the fabric so that it is tight in two diffent dirrections (pullling away from the center of the panel). The way I’m describing this might be confusing and I can elaborate further if it is helpful.
-The 2 by 4s at the bottom are 15" long so they extend an extra 3 inches on each side of the panel and that ended up feeling very stable.

author: EliHeathMusic
content:
Thanks everyone! Okay so they are 73" by 33" and 9" deep and I double framed them with 1/2 inch plywood (interior structural frame that I stretched the fabric onto and an exterior trim frame with nicer looking wood). Cost roughly $215 per panel and I built them over about 3 afternoons.

Materials for two panels:
(1) half inch 4 by 8 sheet of rough framing plywood (plus some extra scraps I had to complete the bracing)
(1) half inch 4 by 8 sheet of nicer looking trim plywood
(1) 6 foot long 1”x1” square dowel to brace corners
(1) 8 foot 2 by 4 for the base 
(8) locking 2” caster wheels 
(2) bags of Rockwool safe n sound (47”x15.25”x3”)
(1) can of Behr wood stain (I used a water based version in the “mission oak” color)
(9) yards of fabric at least 40 inches wide (I had leftover Guilford of Maine Sona fabric in the cream color and did the backs with stuff I got at Joann Fabric 
(1) pack of 5/16 inch staples for fabric

1”, 1.5” and 2.5” screws. I used about (120) of the 1” ones for most of the framing and trim pieces, (24) of the 1.5” to attach the trapazoid supports at the bottom and (12) 2.5” ones to attach the 2 by 4s to the panels
